quote: First Officer's Log, Stardate 48521.5.     Odo and I are returning to Deep Space    Nine after reviewing security    procedures at Prophet's Landing, the    Bajoran Colony closest to the    Cardassian Border.
Those orbital sensor platforms should    give the colonists plenty of advanced    warning in case the Cardassians ever    decide to violate the new treaty.
Hopefully.
How did your meeting with Security    Chief Bemar go?
Fine.
I assume he was properly impressed    by the depth of your expertise.
Odo, is something bothering you?
What makes you say that?
For one thing, you haven't said more    than five words to me since we left    Prophet's Landing.
Look, if I've done something to offend    you I wish you'd tell me what it is.
It's nothing.
No.  It's something.  So you might    as well talk about it.  It might    make you feel better.
Nevermind.  Forget I asked.
It's not important.
Whatever you say.
It's certainly not worth making an    issue about.
I'm glad to hear it.
It's just... when Governor Avesta    invited us to dinner at his house...
Go on.
You said no.
And?
You never bothered to ask me if I    wanted to go.
You wanted to go to dinner at the    governor's house?
Not particularly.
Then what's the problem?
The problem is... you never asked    what I wanted.
I'm sorry... I just thought that you    wouldn't want to go.
How could you know for certain if    you never asked?
Odo... you don't eat!       Besides, you hate socializing with    people you don't know.
That's beside the point.  I would've    liked to have been consulted, that's    all.
You're right.       Next time we're invited to dinner,    I'll let you be the one to say no.
I'd appreciate that.
Hold on, I'm picking up a wide band    subspace transmission from a Lissepian    supply ship.  They were just attacked    by a Maquis interceptor.
Long range sensors are detecting a    modified Peregrine Class courier    ship, lightly armed, one man crew,    bearing two-six-eight mark three-oh-   one.
The Maquis use Peregrine Class courier    ships.       The Lissepians didn't sustain any    serious damage.  I'm going after    him.
Right.
O'Brien to Sisko.
Go ahead.
Commander, there's... someone here    to see you.
Who is it?
(can't believe it     himself)   It's... Nog, sir.
Nog.
Tell him it's urgent.
He says it's urgent.
Send him in.
I told you he'd see me.
Commander, first let me express my    most sincere thanks for allowing me    to speak with you.
You're welcome.  Now what's this all    about?
I wanted to give you... this.
Open it.
What's this?
It's latinum.
I know it's latinum.  Why are you    giving it to me?
Yesterday I completed the Ferengi    Attainment Ceremony.       I'm an adult.
Congratulations.
Thank you.
But that still doesn't explain this.

It's my life's savings.  According    to Ferengi Bylaws, section one-oh-   five, subparagraph ten, upon reaching    adulthood, Ferengi males must purchase    an apprenticeship from a suitable    role model.       I choose you.
You want to be my apprentice?
That's right.  I want to be the first    Ferengi in Starfleet.  Now who do I    see about getting a uniform?
Nog, I'm afraid it doesn't work that    way.  We don't just give Starfleet    uniforms to anyone.
I understand.
But a man of your stature could    undoubtedly arrange something.  One    day, I plan on being a commander    just like you.
Nog, if you want to be a Starfleet    Officer, you have to attend the    Academy.
(thinks about it for     a beat)   All right.  Where do I sign up?
It's not that simple.  As a non-   Federation citizen, you need a letter    of reference from a command level    officer before you can even take the    entrance exam.
A command level officer?  You mean,    like you?
Yes.  Like me.
Perfect.  Is it a form letter or    would you like me to help you write    it?
Tell me Nog... why do you want to    join Starfleet?  Why not serve aboard    a Ferengi ship?
Are you saying that, as a Ferengi,    I'm not good enough to join Starfleet?
Not at all.
Then you'll write the letter.
I'll think about it.
Thank you, Commander.  I know you'll    make the right decision.
Hold on.
Aren't you forgetting something?
Keep it.  Consider it a token of my    appreciation.
I don't know what the Maquis have    done to that ship's engines, but    it's fast.
Not fast enough.  We're closing on    him.
We'd better catch him soon.  We're    entering the Badlands.
Clever.  He probably knows this    territory a lot better than we do.
Now aren't you glad I didn't accept    that dinner invitation.  If I had,    we would've missed all this    excitement.
That would've been a pity.       Wait a minute... I've lost him.  The    Badlands' plasma fields are disrupting    our sensors.
Increase the sensor bandwidth.  That    should compensate for the    interference.
I hope you're right.
He couldn't have gotten far. He's    probably somewhere in this solar    system.
There he is.  It looks like he's    headed for one of the moons orbiting    that gas giant.
I'm following him in.
Something's wrong with his ship.  It    looks like his attitude stabilizers    have failed.
Can we get a transporter lock on    him?
There's too much interference.
He's trying to land on that moon.
We've lost him.
Did he make it?
I don't know.  Something in the moon's    atmosphere is jamming our sensors.
Then I guess we'll have to land and    see for ourselves.
The tricorders are useless.  The    atmospheric ionization is jamming    their transponders.
You're sure he's in these caverns?
He wasn't in the wreckage of his    ship.  And given the weather    conditions on the surface, there's    no way anyone could survive out there    very long.  So that leaves...
That's the third quake since we    landed.  This moon must be seismically    unstable.
The sooner we find our fugitive, the    better off we'll be.

Finding him isn't going to be easy.     These caverns could go on forever.     And given all this seismic activity,    I don't want to stay here any longer    than we have to.       I say we split up.  We can meet back    here in twenty minutes.  If we haven't    found him by then, we may have to    leave without him.
If he's smart, he'll let us find    him.  A Federation prison would be    paradise compared to this place.
Let's hope he's smart.
I'll see you in twenty minutes.
Kira to Odo.  Odo, do you hear me?
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: This is Odo.  I can barely hear you.
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: Odo, I'm trapped and I need your    help.  Come quickly.  Odo, do you    read me?  This is Kira...
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: Stay where you are, Major.  I'll be    right there.
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: Odo... Odo is that you?
I'm right here, Major.
Odo, am I glad to see you.
What's wrong?
You're not going to believe this...    my foot is stuck.
Stuck?    (makes his way over     to her)   How?
I don't know.  I must've stepped    into a fissure or something.  I can't    get it loose.
Let me take a look.
It's not a fissure.
Then what is it?
Your foot's been encased in some    kind of crystal.  And from the look    of things...
The crystal's spreading.
You're sure you can't pull it loose?
Believe me, I've tried.
Maybe if you slipped your foot out    of your boot.
I can barely feel my foot, the crystal    is pressing against it so hard.     There's no way I can get my boot    off.
Hold on.
This might hurt a little.
Go ahead.
I fail to see the humor in this    situation.
Oh come on, Odo.  You have to admit,    it's pretty ridiculous.       The two of us outsmarted by a chunk    of crystal.
I'm not giving up just yet.
Neither am I.  Hand me my phaser.
It's over there.  By the palm beacon.
You're sure this is a good idea?  If    you're not careful...
I'll blow my foot off and Julian    will have a chance to prove what a    wonderful doctor he is.       Don't worry, I have no intention of    giving him the opportunity.  Now    stand back.
I guess that wasn't a very good idea    after all.
The crystal formation seems to have    somehow fed off the energy from the    phaser.
Odo to Mekong.  Two to beam out.     Energize.
Odo to Mekong.       I can't contact the runabout.  There's    too much interference.  I'll have to    walk back to the landing site and    try to transport you from there.
You're worried about leaving me here?
Now that you mention it, yes.
I'll be fine, Odo.       I promise not to go anywhere.
What about our Maquis fugitive?
If he shows up, I'll make sure he    waits here until you get back.
Nog, hand me that phase matrix    recalibrator.
Here you are, Father.
Is it fixed yet?
Not yet, Brother.
What's taking so long?
We're working as fast as we can.     The replicators' entire power supply    grid has been shorted out.
I told you, Brother, if you don't    shut down your replicators at least    once a week for routine maintenance,    you risk system overloads like this    one.
You said it "might" overload the    system.  "Might."
He tried to warn you, Uncle Quark.     You should've listened to him.
No.  It's my fault.  I should have    explained it better.

Of course it's your fault.  Everything    that goes wrong here is your fault.     It says so in your contract.       This mess better be cleaned up before    lunchtime or I'm taking the losses    out of your pay.
Of course, Brother.
I need to get a replacement power    coupling from the storeroom.  I'll    be right back.
Hey, Nog.  What's going on?
If you're here to order lunch, you'll    have to come back in an hour.
Actually, I just ate.       Hey, that was a pretty funny joke    you pulled on my Dad this morning.    (off Nog's questioning     look)   You know, about wanting to join    Starfleet.
Come on, Nog.  You don't really expect    me to fall for that one.
Did you tell your father I was joking?
Yeah, kind of.
How could you do that to me?  I want    you to go back to your father and    tell him that you were wrong.
All right.  Take it easy.  I mean    how was I supposed to know you were    serious?  You never said you wanted    to join Starfleet before.
I'm saying it now.
So what brought this on?
I have my reasons.
Okay.  Name one.
Why should I?
Cause I'm your friend.  And friends    don't have secrets from one another.
It isn't a secret.  I just don't    want to talk about it.
Why not?
Because it's personal.  Now stop    asking me.
All right.  But my father's a pretty    smart guy.  If this is some kind of    trick, he's going to figure it out.
There's nothing to figure out.  I'm    going to join Starfleet.  And that's    that.    (looks back at the     replicator)   Now if you don't mind, I have work    to do.
Computer, lock onto these coordinates    and initiate transport sequence.
Unable to comply.
Explain.
The high level of atmospheric    ionization is inhibiting transporter    lock.
Can you compensate for the    interference by using pattern    enhancers?
Negative.  Pattern enhancers will    not function in a polarized ionization    field.
Is there any way to achieve a    transporter lock in this kind of    ionization field?
Negative.
Computer, send out a priority one    distress signal to Deep Space Nine.
Unable to comply.  Communications    systems are inoperable due to    atmospheric interference.
In that case, launch a communications    probe and instruct it to begin a    continuous broadcast of our    whereabouts as soon as it clears the    atmosphere.
Working.
Probe launch confirmed.
Computer, given ideal conditions,    how soon can we expect help from    Deep Space Nine?
Deep Space Nine should receive the    probe's distress signal in    approximately two days.
Kira... I heard phaser fire.
You just missed our friend.  He came    out of that tunnel.       I think he was as surprised as I    was.  He fired at me from over there,    but when I shot back he ran off down    the tunnel.
Don't worry, his aim wasn't any better    than mine was.
He didn't miss by much.
This must be my lucky day.
I see you've put in a request to    reassign Ensign Vilix'pran from Cargo    Inspection.
I thought it'd be for the best.     Given his condition, I don't want    him coming in contact with any    hazardous materials.
His condition?
Ensign Vilix'pran is budding.  The    buds will be undergoing individuation    in a little over a month.
You mean... he's pregnant?
Twins.
Reassignment granted.  I'll have to    offer the ensign my congratulations    the next time I see him.
O'Brien and I are throwing him a    baby shower in a couple of days.     I'm sure it'd mean a lot to him if    you were there.
Are you getting him anything?
O'Brien's building him a hatchling    pond and I've already placed an order    with Garak for some baby clothes.
Count me in.
Commander Sisko.
If you'll excuse me, Doctor?
By all means.
So, Commander, have you made up your    mind yet?  About my letter?
Not exactly.
What does that mean, "not exactly?"
Look, Nog, I have to be honest with    you, when I think of candidates for    Starfleet Academy, yours is not the    first name that comes to mind.
Why not?  Because I'm a Ferengi?
Not at all.  The fact is, your    reputation on this station leaves a    lot to be desired.  Your school grades    are mediocre at best, you've had    more than a few run-ins with Constable    Odo...
Okay, I've made some mistakes.  I    admit that.  But I can do better.     Just give me a chance.
You wanted to see me, Benjamin?
Lieutenant, I need a complete    inventory on the contents of Cargo    Bay Twelve.
Didn't we inventory Twelve last week?
I'd like it done again.
All right.  I'll assign a crew to it    immediately.
Actually, I already have someone in    mind for the job.
Really?  Who?
Nog.
Nog?
He's asked for a recommendation to    Starfleet Academy.
Nog.
My reaction exactly.
I've always thought it would be    interesting to have a Ferengi in    Starfleet, but Nog?
I know it seems unlikely, but before    I make up my mind, I want to give    him a chance to prove himself.
Commander, there's a lot of valuable    equipment in Cargo Bay Twelve.
I know.
Maybe I'd better assign a couple of    crewmembers to... assist him.
No.  I want him to do it alone.  No    help.  No interference.  And no one    looking over his shoulder.
I wish I could analyze this material.
Too bad our tricorders don't work.
Or our communicators... or the    transporter.  Our fugitive couldn't    have picked a better place to hide.     Very convenient, don't you think?
You make it sound like he planned on    trapping us.
Maybe he did.  But it's not going to    work.  I'm going to get you out of    here.
How much longer do you think I have,    Odo?
Long enough.
I figure if the crystal keeps growing    at its current rate, it'll cover me    completely in less than twelve hours.
Unless this cave collapses first.
(his frustration     leaking through)   There has to be a way to shatter the    crystal.
I'm sure there is.  But that    doesn't mean that we're going to    find it in the next twelve hours.
We'll find it.
Odo, maybe you should go back to    Deep Space Nine.
We're too far away.  Even if they    sent a rescue team right now, they'd    never make it here in time.
Maybe not, but there's no point in    both of us being buried here.
You mean you want me to leave?
You've done all you can.
Major, I haven't even begun yet.
Oh, I see.  So everything you've    done up until now has only been... a    warmup exercise.
(trying to raise her     spirits)   Exactly.  I've just been lulling    this crystal into a false sense of    security.
I think it's working.
Major, do you ever look at the    Criminal Activity Reports we get    from Starfleet Security?
Not often.
You should.  They make fascinating
So all we have to do is find some    Nausicaan raiders and ask them to    give us a hand.

I might be able to put together a    makeshift generator using the    covariant oscillator from the    runabout.  The trick will be finding    the right frequency to create a    sympathetic vibration inside this    crystal.       I'll have to go back to the runabout    and start assembling the generator.     Keep your phaser ready in case our    friend comes back.
I will.
I'll be back as soon as I can.
Constable.       When we get back to the station, I'm    going to start reading those Criminal    Activity Reports.
I'll make sure you get them.
Due to a computer error, we lost the    manifest on this entire cargo bay.     Commander Sisko would like you to re-   inventory the contents.
Of the entire cargo bay?
That's right.
By myself?
Look Nog, Starfleet isn't only about    exploration and diplomacy.  A lot of    the time, it's just hard work.
When does Commander Sisko want it    done?
He'd like the manifest on his desk    first thing tomorrow morning.
He'll have it tonight, before he    goes off duty.
Tomorrow morning will be fine.
Now if you don't mind, Lieutenant,    I'd like to get started.
What's wrong?
It's getting a little snug in here,    that's all.
How long do you think it'll take the    generator to find the right frequency?
It's hard to say.  It could take    hours.
I don't suppose there's any way to    speed things up?
I didn't think so.
Don't worry, Major.  I have every    intention of getting us back to the    station by tomorrow night.  Chief    O'Brien is counting on it.
What does O'Brien have to do with    it?
(doesn't want to get     into it)   We have... an appointment.
What kind of appointment?
Talk to me, Odo.  It'll help pass    the time.
The Chief and I are supposed to go    kayaking together... in a holosuite.
You're kidding.  How did he talk you    into that?
He didn't talk me into anything.       It's really quite enjoyable.
You mean you've done it before?
Twice.  He invited me one evening    and, seeing I had no other plans, I    accepted.
I'm sorry.  I'm just having a little    trouble picturing you and O'Brien    together in a boat.
Well if it helps any, he's the one    who does all the singing.
He sings?
He says it's necessary to establish    a smooth paddling rhythm.
This gets better and better.       What kind of songs does he sing?
Ancient human sea chanties, mostly.     He's particularly fond of one called    "Louie, Louie."
I never knew O'Brien was so...    nautical.
Next to his work and his family,    "shooting the rapids" is his favorite    activity.  He's had the holo-program    since he was on the Enterprise.
So how long do these boat trips    usually take?
That depends.
On what?
On how many times we capsize.       The truth is, Major, Chief O'Brien's    never completed the entire program.
Not once?
Not in seven years of trying.
It must be a very difficult program.
Extremely difficult.  According to    him, he's dislocated his shoulder a    half dozen times trying to make it    down those rapids.
Then why does he keep doing it?
Because he loves it.  And it's been    my observation that you humanoids    have a hard time giving up the things    you love... no matter how much they    might hurt you.
I should check the equipment.
The equipment's fine.       I'm glad you're here, Odo.
I'm glad I'm here, too.
(alarmed, reacting to     what she sees)   Odo...
Major?
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I'm all right.  What about the    generator?
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: It's fine.  But it still hasn't found    the right frequency to shatter the    crystal.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Tell it to hurry.  A few more tremors    like that last one and this whole    cave will collapse.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Then we'll have to make sure we're    not here when that happens.  After    all, we've been in worse situations    than this one and come out all right.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Name three.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I can't think of any either.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: It's not that.  It's just... That    wasn't the response I expected.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: What do you mean?
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: In the detective novels Chief O'Brien    gives me to read, when the hero says,    "We've been in tougher scrapes than    this one," his friends always agree.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I never read any of those books.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: There must be some humanoid platitude    I can use to cheer you up.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I'm afraid I don't have much use for    platitudes, Odo.  I'd rather just    face the truth about a situation and    go on from there.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I feel the same way.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I know.That's why you and I get along    so well.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I suppose it is.  But in this case,    the truth is we are going to get you    out of here, Major.  And that's no    platitude.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I have to admit, this is impressive    work.
Incredible is more like it.  He    inventoried the whole cargo bay in    under five hours.
You're sure he didn't have any help?
According to the internal sensors,    no one else entered that cargo bay    for the entire time he was there.
I guess he learned a few things    working in his uncle's storeroom.    (trying to put it     delicately)   I assume all our equipment is still...    where it's supposed to be?
If you're asking if he stole anything,    the answer is no.  He even found    some items we missed during our last    inventory.
Okay, so we know he's a hard worker,    but the question remains: Why does    he want to join Starfleet?
I have no idea.
So we still can't be sure if he's    serious or if this is all part of    some elaborate scam.
Commander, we need to talk.
Go right ahead.
It's about my nephew.
Somehow, I'm not surprised.
Rom, tell Commander Sisko what's on    your mind.
Well, the thing is... I'm not quite    sure...
What my brother's trying to say is    he's furious that you'd even consider    allowing his son to attend Starfleet    Academy.       Isn't that right?
Well, I...
You see.  He can barely speak he's    so angry.  Now we... I mean, he...    demands you refuse the boy's request    and return his latinum immediately.
Rom, is that what you want?
The thing is... we've always    assumed... that is... I did promise    that Nog would become... my brother's    apprentice...
That explains things.
Lieutenant, please, this is between    my brother and Commander Sisko.
Actually, that's not true.  Your...    brother's feelings aren't at issue    here.  According to both Federation    law and Ferengi tradition, Nog is    old enough to make his own decisions.
You see, brother, I told you.
And as for the latinum, must I remind    you of the first Rule of Acquisition?
"Once you have their money, you never    give it back."  It's one of my    brother's favorites.       Isn't that so, Brother?
I'm not going to stand here and argue    Rules of Acquisition with a human.
Especially one who knows them as    well as you.
(ignoring her, to     Sisko)   That apprenticeship money is    rightfully mine.  And I will protest    your actions to the Nagus himself if    I have to.
Give the Nagus my best.
Can we leave now, brother?
Would you stop calling me that?
Calling you what?
"Brother."
But you are my brother.       Unless mother lied to us.
If only that were true.
So I take it you are going to write    Nog's letter of recommendation?
I don't know.  That depends on Nog.

I don't understand it.  I've run    through the entire harmonic spectrum    and none of the frequencies have had    an effect on the crystal.  It's almost    as if the structure of the crystal    is mutating to keep us from finding    the right frequency.
Odo.
Yes, Major.
I wish there was something else I    could do...
Just keep talking to me.
What do you want me to say?
Anything.  Tell me a story.
A story?
I know.  Tell me how you got your    name.
My name?  Come to think of it, that    is an amusing story.
Tell it to me.

Well, as you know, when Doctor Mora    first brought me to his laboratory,    it was under Cardassian supervision.     All specimens had to be clearly    labeled in Cardassian, so that the    overseers would always know what the    scientists were working on.  Since    no one could decide exactly what I    was, Mora labelled me "Unknown    Sample," which the overseer translated    into Cardassian as "Odo'ital."
So your name is "Unknown Sample?"

No.  "Odo'ital" literally means    "Nothing."  Even after it became    clear that I was sentient, the Bajoran    scientists kept calling me that.  As    a joke, they split it into two words,    like a Bajoran name: "Odo Ital."     Which eventually got shortened...
To Odo.

But the thing is, for the longest    time, when anyone spoke my name, the    first thing I'd think of was what it    meant: "Nothing."  What better way    to describe me?  I had no family, no    friends, no place where I belonged.
I thought it was the most appropriate    name anyone could give me.       And then I met you...
And the others.  Sisko, Dax, even    Quark.  And now, when I hear one of    you call me "Odo," I no longer think    of myself as "Nothing."  I think of    myself as... me.
I'm sorry, Major.  I guess that story    wasn't as amusing as I'd hoped it    would be.
No.  I liked it very much.
The ultrasonic generator isn't going    to work, is it?
No, I'm afraid it's not.
I don't suppose you have any other    ideas.
I wish I had.
If it makes you feel better, I don't    have any either.
It just doesn't make sense.  The    ultrasonic generator should have    worked.  Something's not right here.
Odo, you've done your best.  Now I    think it's time for you to go.
Go?
This place could collapse at any    minute.  That Maquis has probably    been killed already by one of the    cave-ins.  There's nothing more you    can do for me.
If you're asking me to leave...
No.  I know you wouldn't listen to    me.
You're right about that.
So as your superior officer, I'm    telling you to take the runabout and    get the hell off this moon.       That's an order.
Odo, what are you standing there    for?  I told you to get out of here.
I'm not leaving.
Constable, I gave you a direct order.
You can order me all you want.  As    of now, I'm resigning my commission.
Odo, if you stay here, you'll die.
You don't know that for certain.     And even if it were true, I'm not    going to abandon you.
But I want you to go.
Don't you understand?  I can't.
You have to.
Please, Odo.
No.  I won't leave you.
Why not?
Because...       Because, I'm in love with you.
So now you know.
Odo...
I'm in love with you, too.
You wanted to see me, Commander?
Nog I've given your request a lot of    thought.
I appreciate that, Commander.
But I'm afraid I have to turn you    down.
Turn me down?  Why?  Did I do    something wrong?
It's not anything you did, Nog.     You're just not Academy material.
Here.  This belongs to you.
Commander, can't we talk about this?
There's nothing to talk about.  We    both know you'd never make it through    the Academy.  You couldn't handle    the workload or the discipline.  You    wouldn't last two weeks.
That's not true.  I'm a hard worker.     I proved that to you.
It doesn't matter.  I'm not going to    place my reputation on the line just    to satisfy some whim of yours.
It's not just a whim.  I'm serious    about joining Starfleet.
I don't have time for this, Nog.     Whatever little scheme you had, you    can forget it.  You're not getting    that letter.
It's not a joke... or a scheme.  I    want to join Starfleet.  I want it    more than I've ever wanted anything    in my life.
You're a Ferengi.  Why would you    want to be in Starfleet?  Where's    the profit in it?
I don't care about profit.
Then what do you care about?  Come    on, Nog, tell me.  Why is it so damned    important for you to get into    Starfleet?  Why are you doing this?
(finally blurts out     the truth)   Because I don't want to end up like    my father.
Your father.

That's right.  My father.  He's been    chasing after profit his whole life.     And what has it gotten him?  Nothing.     And you know why?  Because he doesn't    have the lobes.       And neither do I.
And "A Ferengi without profit... "
"... Is no Ferengi at all."
The eighteenth Rule of Acquisition.

My father's a mechanical genius.  He    could've been the chief engineer of    a starship if he'd had the    opportunity.  But he went into    business instead, like a good Ferengi.     The only thing is, he's not a good    Ferengi... not when it comes to    acquiring profit.  So now all he has    to live for is the slim chance that    someday, somehow, he might be able    to take over my uncle's bar.  Well    I'm not going to make the same    mistake.  I want to do something    with my life... something worthwhile.
Like joining Starfleet.
I might not have an instinct for    business, but I've got my father's    hands and my uncle's tenacity.  I    know I've got something to offer, I    just need a chance to prove it.
All right.  I'll see to it you get    that chance.
You'll recommend me to Starfleet    Academy?
I'll send the letter first thing    tomorrow morning.
Commander, I don't know how to thank    you.
Don't thank me yet.  You've got a    lot of work ahead of you.
Don't worry.  You'll never regret    this.
Odo?
Yes, Major.
You haven't said a word in almost an    hour.
I've just been going over a few things    in my mind.
You've been thinking about me, haven't    you?
I'm sorry that it took so long for    me to tell you how I feel about you.     Maybe if I'd told you earlier, things    would've been different.
What are you smiling about?

(still looking at the     phaser hits)   I think I've finally figured out    what's going on here.  This whole    situation hasn't seemed right since    the beginning.  There've been too    many coincidences, too many unanswered    questions.
Are you still trying to prove this    is some kind of conspiracy?
You said the Maquis was standing    about here when he fired at you?
That's right.
How tall was he?  My height?
No.  Maybe a little shorter.
Like this?
More or less.  Why does it matter    anyway?
It matters because from this position,    you're blocking those phaser hits.
There's no way someone standing here    could've hit those rocks without    hitting you first.
Maybe he was standing somewhere else.
Maybe.  Or maybe you were lying to    me.  Which makes two times you've    lied to me today.
What are you talking about?
You lied when you said you were shot    at by the Maquis.  And you lied when    you said you loved me.

I wish you did.  But you don't.       Remember Major, I pride myself on my    ability to observe human nature.     And I've watched you for the past    three years.  In all that time, I    never saw the slightest indication    that you had those kinds of feelings    for me.  You like me.  You think of    me as a close friend... but love?     I'm afraid not.
Maybe I said I loved you because I    thought it'd make you feel better.     Because I thought it was what you    wanted to hear.
You're lying again.  The Kira I know    values our friendship far too much    to lie to me, even for the best of    reasons.
Odo... I can explain...
Good.  You can start by telling me    who you are and what you've done    with Kira.
Well done, Odo.  You really are quite    a skillful investigator.
And you're quite a skillful    changeling.
You still have much to learn.
If you want to share your wisdom    with me, you can start by telling me    where Major Kira is.
Close by.
You were the fugitive we were chasing,    weren't you?
That's correct.
How'd you get your hands on a Maquis    ship?
Now, Odo, you can't expect me to    give you all the answers.
But why did you lead us here?  And    why replace Kira?
I needed to understand why you chose    to live with the Solids rather than    your own people.  I suspected it had    something to do with Major Kira.       And now I'm certain of it.
So your plan was to let me think she    died.  You thought that would take    away my link to the Solids.
And then you would return to us.
I assure you, nothing will ever make    me do that.
I wouldn't be so sure.
(still aiming the     phaser)   Tell me where she is.
And if I don't, then what?  You'll    shoot me?       No changeling has ever harmed another.
There's a first time for everything.

Major Kira is down that tunnel, two    hundred meters south of here.  Save    her if it suits you.       But it won't make any difference.     She's never going to love you.  How    could she?  You're a changeling.
Major.  Wake up.
Odo, what happened?  How did I get    here...
It's a long story.  Right now we    have to get you to the Mekong.
There's one thing I still don't    understand.  If that Founder wanted    to test your allegiance to the Solids,    why did she impersonate me?
I suppose it's because you happened    to be with me in the runabout.  It    could just as easily have been    Commander Sisko... or Doctor Bashir.
So what finally made you realize the    truth?
Eventually she made a mistake.  She    said something I know you would never    say.
And what was that?
Just a slip of the tongue.  Nothing    important.
I tell you, I won't stand for it.     No nephew of mine is going to disgrace    our family name by joining Starfleet.
But Uncle Quark...
My mind is made up.  I forbid it.
No you don't.
Rom, stay out of this.
I will not.  When it comes to the    bar, you may be in charge, but when    it comes to my son, I make the    decisions.
Then you tell him he can't go.
I'll do no such thing.
What?
Nog.  Good luck.  I would be proud    to have a son in Starfleet.
You're both insane.
Like father, like son.
